data.name: AboutMessageLine1
data.value: My name is Ben Barrett, and I am a software engineer by day, and avid gamer by night.

data.name: AboutMessageLine2
data.value: My goal for this project has primarily been to fill the role of an in-game profile, but I believe HotS will be a very popular game in the future, so I want to expand HOTS Logs to include more detailed analysis of individual replays. I want this site to inspire players to better themselves, and learn something about their play styles or team composition.

data.name: ChooseBattleNetIdErrorMessage1
data.value: Sorry, we couldn't find your BattleTag. It should be in this format: 'Nickname#123'

data.name: ChooseBattleNetIdErrorMessage2
data.value: No replays found with that Battle.Net Id. Please follow this link to upload a replay and verify this user.

data.name: ChooseBattleNetIdMessageLine1
data.value: Please enter your Heroes of the Storm BattleTag:

data.name: DefaultIntroMessageLine1
data.value: The best site dedicated to analyzing Heroes of the Storm replay files.

data.name: DefaultIntroMessageLine2
data.value: This site is still in its early stages, but there is good information to be had, and plenty more to come.

data.name: DefaultIntroMessageLine3Part1
data.value: Check the menu above for information currently available.

data.name: DefaultIntroMessageLine3Part2
data.value: Registration is free, so please sign up and start analyzing your replays!

data.name: DefaultIntroMessageTotalGames
data.value: Thank you to everyone for your participation! So far, everyone has uploaded a total of {0} games!

data.name: ErrorPageMessageLine1
data.value: Looks like we had an error! An admin has been emailed, and will look into it in the future.

data.name: ErrorPageMessageLine2
data.value: Please try your action again later.

data.name: FAQMessageLine01
data.value: Why are replays missing from my match history?

data.name: FAQMessageLine02
data.value: There is an option in Heroes of the Storm to save all your replays. Unfortunately, if you didn't know about this or didn't enable it early on, only your most recent replays will be saved.

data.name: FAQMessageLine03
data.value: The good news is that if another player uploads one of the games you were in previously, it will be added to your Profile as well.

data.name: FAQMessageLine04
data.value: When is MMR calculated? When is the leaderboard updated?

data.name: FAQMessageLine05
data.value: MMR is constantly being recalculated. There are two separate priorities here: Replays uploaded within {0} days of playing are usually calculated within a few hours. Newly uploaded games that were played within the previous two months are usually calculated within a couple weeks. Newly uploaded games that were played more than two months ago will unfortunately not have MMR calculated. This is because it is currently too demanding to have to recalculate all past games. This system is set up to keep MMR as fresh as possible for players who use HOTS Logs at least once every three days :)

data.name: FAQMessageLine06
data.value: Can players upload only their wins to raise themselves on the leaderboard?

data.name: FAQMessageLine07
data.value: Yes and no. If they only upload wins, their MMR will be unnaturally raised. But Blizzard knows better and will continue to match them appropriately. Only having wins against players with MMR lower than the falsified one will result in smaller and smaller gains.

data.name: FAQMessageLine08
data.value: There is also the same 'good news' above; if other players upload some of the losses, they will be added to both profiles.

data.name: FAQMessageLine09
data.value: Thankfully, I've looked through a number of profiles and haven't found anyone with unusually large win streaks.

data.name: FAQMessageLine10
data.value: Why do some of my uploaded replays show as Duplicate?

data.name: FAQMessageLine11
data.value: This simply means one of the other 9 players in that game has already uploaded that replay. Don't worry, it will be added to all of the involved players' profiles, including yours.

data.name: GenericErrorConfirmPasswordDoesntMatch
data.value: The password and confirmation password do not match.

data.name: GenericErrorConfirmPasswordRequired
data.value: The confirm password field is required.

data.name: GenericErrorEmailRequired
data.value: The email address field is required

data.name: GenericErrorUserNameRequired
data.value: The user name field is required

data.name: GenericExcludingMirrorMatchupsAndTalentGatedHeroes
data.value: Excluding Mirror Matchups and Talent Gated Heroes

data.name: GenericExcludingTalentGatedGamesAndAutoSelectGames
data.value: Excluding Talent Gated Games and Auto Select Games

data.name: LeaderboardLeagueGamesPlayedRequirement
data.value: This league requires players to upload at least {0} replays

data.name: LeaderboardMMRInfoLink
data.value: If you would like more information on how I calculate MMR, I've written up a little explanation here

data.name: LogInForgotPassword
data.value: Forgot your password? Click here to reset your login credentials.

data.name: LogInNewUser
data.value: Register if you don't have an account.

data.name: ManageAccountErrorCurrentPasswordRequired
data.value: The current password field is required.

data.name: MatchHistoryMessageLine1
data.value: Click the arrow on the far left column of the table to expand the match and see player details

data.name: MatchHistoryMessageLine2Version2
data.value: Match History MMR is continuously being calculated. Games uploaded within 3 days of playing are usually calculated within a few hours. Games uploaded later than that can take two weeks or more depending on timing. For quickest results, please try to upload games at least once every 3 days.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine02
data.value: I use an algorithm similar to Microsoft's TrueSkill, as this is generally agreed to be better than ELO for team games.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine03
data.value: Your MMR rating shows your skill level compared to other players. As this reflects skill, playing more games will not raise your MMR by itself. If you want to raise your MMR, you'll need to get better :)

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine04
data.value: After each game, your MMR is updated based on the result of the game, as well as the current average MMR of each team.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine05
data.value: If you were matched against a team with MMR higher than your team, and you win, your MMR will be raised more than normal. Similarly, if you are matched against a team of lesser skill, and lose to them, your MMR will drop more than normal.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine06
data.value: With MMR fluctuating like this, after playing for awhile, you should end up with a pretty accurate MMR, and a win rate pretty close to 50%.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine08
data.value: I've put together different 'leagues,' which essentially breaks up the leaderboard. I want players of all levels to find value in this site, and with one leaderboard it is kind of overwhelming to start at the very bottom. Having leagues gives you some milestones to work towards.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine09
data.value: Different leagues also means I can have different requirements for each league. As time goes on and more replays are uploaded, I will likely make more games required in order to be listed on the top leagues. I'll always keep the entry requirement into the bottom leagues lower, so newer players can hopefully see themselves on the list pretty quick.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine10
data.value: Leagues are just splitting up players by MMR into groups. After excluding players with less than 10 games played, Master League is the top 1%, Diamond is the next 9%, Platinum / Gold / Silver are each 20%, and Bronze is the final 30% of players.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine11
data.value: Can't find yourself on the leaderboard? Your MMR may place you in a higher league, but you don't have the required number of games to be eligible. The MMR markers for each league are calculated before checking if players have the required number of games.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine13
data.value: When you play your first game, the system does not know how good you are, so you start with a default MMR. Your earlier games are weighed more heavily in order to speed up the process of finding the best place for you, and as you play more games, they will have less and less of an impact on your MMR.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine14
data.value: This means that your wins and losses early on will change your MMR significantly in both directions.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine15
data.value: This is common for games with matchmaking, and usually helps in quickly getting you matched against players of your skill level.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine16
data.value: This does not mean you are 'stuck' after you've played a few hundred games - it just means your MMR doesn't shift as drastically as it does in your first few games.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine18
data.value: Some players have contacted me, asking to remove certain games, or give them 'fresh starts' because they did not know their early games were their 'placement' matches.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine19
data.value: Starting with a losing streak is unfortunate, but so is starting with a winning streak. For example, I won all 5 of my first placement matches in Starcraft 2, and got placed in Gold league. I was so excited, I bragged to my friends who were placed in Bronze or Silver. I knew I had some lucky games, but the end result is what matters. And then I lost 13 games in a row and was dropped to Bronze. I shouldn't have been placed in Gold league to begin with, and as time went on and I played more games, Blizzard's matchmaking became more confident and accurate, and I started winning 50% of my games.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine20
data.value: The reverse is true here: If you had a losing streak in your 'placement matches' on HOTS Logs, then you will start with a pretty low MMR. If this is inaccurate, and your MMR truly should be higher, Blizzard will be placing you against teams with higher MMR. If you win 50% of your games against players with MMR higher than you, your MMR will slowly climb up to theirs.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine21
data.value: Unfortunately, if your MMR has indeed been inaccurately affected by a losing streak in your placement matches, the solution is to just play more games. It may take more games than if you had won some of your placement matches, but your MMR will end up where it should be eventually. The solution here is not to delete the replay, though; this would remove the replay from the other 9 players in the match as well, and we need more replays uploaded in order to be confident in MMR calculations.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine23
data.value: Some players have contacted me about MMR accuracy, believing they should be higher on the leaderboard.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine24
data.value: Firstly, make sure you have played a good amount of games. When you start out, your MMR is unknown to me, and the system has to guess at your skill. Don't spend too much time thinking about MMR if you haven't uploaded at least 100 replays, and preferably more.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine25
data.value: If you have a lot of replays uploaded, how can you determine if the MMR I calculate is accurate? Look at the individual players' MMR in your matches, and each team's average MMR. Generally, each team's average MMR should be pretty similar.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine26
data.value: There are times where MMR isn't accurate. In cases where established players have only uploaded a few replays, their true MMR is unknown to me, while Blizzard probably has a pretty good idea of it. If a player's change in MMR after a match is significant (a change greater than ~50), that player's skill is still somewhat unknown to me, and I have to make guesses on what their MMR actually should be.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine27
data.value: The best way to improve the accuracy of my calculated MMR is to upload more games :) Ask your friends to upload theirs; the more replays I can look through, the more confident I can be about skill levels.

data.name: MMRInfoMessageLine28
data.value: On a related note, it is encouraging to see many of the more famous pro-gamers in the top 100 of the leaderboard, as well as in matches against eachother :)

data.name: PlayerSearchNoPlayersFound
data.value: No players found, try searching again using the Search box at the top of the page.

data.name: SpecialThanksLine1
data.value: A big 'Thank You!' to Trey Cook at http://dreamweb.co/ for creating our cool logo!

data.name: UploadMessageLine1
data.value: Before you get started uploading, please read:

data.name: UploadMessageLine2
data.value: I plan to make everyone's replay data as accessible as possible, with the exception of in game chat, which I will never make available. Other than that restriction, the data within replays uploaded will essentially be public.

data.name: UploadMessageLine3
data.value: Currently I am accepting Storm League, Quick Match, and Custom Game replays. Custom games are private and only visible to users who have verified their account through Battle.Net.

data.name: UploadMessageLine4
data.value: Successfully parsed replays only need to be uploaded once. I will save the replay file, and when I make advancements in the data I can pull from replays, I will automatically update your replay statistics.

data.name: UploadMessageLine5
data.value: If you get a 'Duplicate' error when uploading a replay, that means that you OR someone else in that match has already uploaded that replay.

data.name: UploadMessageLine6
data.value: If you get an error when uploading a file, you can try again later. I am continuously fixing issues, and may be able to pull information from your failed uploads later on.

data.name: UploadMessageSingleReplayLine1
data.value: Note: The default folder for replays is:

data.name: UploadMessageUploaderLine2
data.value: I recommend using a small Windows application I wrote to upload your replay files automatically:

data.name: UploadMessageUploaderLine3
data.value: Click here to download the HOTS Logs Uploader
